titleStmt.title: Forms V and VI PFV sound verbs

sourceDesc.p: This is the feature-file for derived form V and VI PFV sound verbs (tkassar, tikassar?) pattern + example.

revisionDesc.change: For EGY-___ there are no values found
updating references to Zotero IDs via update-bibl-refs.xsl

cit.quote: he was slow, he took his time

wib:featureValueObservation.note: "In the perfect an initial CC cluster is generally formed: tʕallam (he learned), etc." (Pickett 2005:245)
"In the perfect an initial CC cluster is generally formed: tʕallam (he learned), etc." (Pickett 2005:245)
"In the perfect an initial CC cluster is generally formed: tʕallam (he learned), etc." (Pickett 2005:245)
"In the perfect an initial CC cluster is generally formed: tʕallam (he learned), etc." (Pickett 2005:245)
"In the perfect an initial CC cluster is generally formed: tʕallam (he learned), etc." (Pickett 2005:245)
"In the perfect an initial CC cluster is generally formed: tʕallam (he learned), etc." (Pickett 2005:245)
Judging by the examples provided by Younes, it seems that form V consistently takes ti- preffix while in form VI the vowel i sometimes is elided t(i)-.
Forms V and VI (t-prefix) also function to derive passives, and, in the case of Form VI, there is a sense of reciprocity.
The reflexive forms V and VI have the performative (i)t- in the perfect, which is a feature typical of the sedentary dialcts of the area. (Palva 1989:235)

cit.quote: to have an argument with each other

wib:featureValueObservation.note: no example for form VI available.

cit.quote: he blessed sb., he congratulated sb.
to have an argument with each other
he splits himself into many parts

wib:featureValueObservation.note: t(a)- is also given for From VI
This form seems to be only applicable to certain verbs in Form VI.

cit.quote: he came to blows / he clashed
he shot someone / something, he hunted
he was aware of, he realized

wib:featureValueObservation.note: The variant tubārak is also given for Form VI
It is not certain that the vowel is conditioned.
If first radical is a guttural, the prefix is ta-, e.g., taharraǧ he had a conversation
If first radical is a guttural, the prefix is ta-, e.g., taʕallam he learned
